content.$t: headline: Tax Reform Act of 1969, text: With the passage of the Tax Reform Act of 1969, Congress creates a separate funding stream for nonprofit regulation through a tax on private foundations – which Congress fails to appropriate for the intended purpose. , media: https://s3.amazonaws.com/iw-files/images/2014/IRS_timeline/IRSlogo.png, mediacredit: WikiCommons

gsx$text.$t: With the passage of the Tax Reform Act of 1969, Congress creates a separate funding stream for nonprofit regulation through a tax on private foundations – which Congress fails to appropriate for the intended purpose.

content.$t: enddate: 1980, headline: IRS defies pressure from Nixon, text: President Richard Nixon's administration pressures the agency to audit tax returns of his opponents. Three IRS Commissioners consecutively appointed by Nixon refuse. Their defiance symbolizes the agency's goal of being an independent regulator.

gsx$text.$t: President Richard Nixon's administration pressures the agency to audit tax returns of his opponents. Three IRS Commissioners consecutively appointed by Nixon refuse. Their defiance symbolizes the agency's goal of being an independent regulator.

content.$t: headline: Commissioner Thrower leads defiance, text: Nixon fires one of the commissioners, Randolph Thrower. As the story goes, he returns a few years later for a visit to the agency. Employees hear that he’s in the building and they stream into the hallways to greet him with applause., media: http://iw-files.s3.amazonaws.com/images/2014/IRS_timeline/ThrowerWaPo.jpg, mediacredit: Bob Burchette/The Washington Post, mediacaption: Former IRS Commissioner Randalph Thrower

gsx$text.$t: Nixon fires one of the commissioners, Randolph Thrower. As the story goes, he returns a few years later for a visit to the agency. Employees hear that he’s in the building and they stream into the hallways to greet him with applause.

content.$t: headline: IRS tests for racial descrimination met with protest, text: The IRS proposes a test to determine if a private school is racially discriminatory — and therefore doesn’t qualify for tax exemptions. The proposal is met with a "firestorm of protest.", media: http://iw-files.s3.amazonaws.com/images/2014/IRS_timeline/thurmondIRS.jpg, mediacredit: Senate.gov, mediacaption: Senator Strom Thurmon was a vocal apponent of the IRS proposal to test if private schools met desegregation standards

gsx$headline.$t: IRS tests for racial descrimination met with protest

gsx$text.$t: The IRS proposes a test to determine if a private school is racially discriminatory — and therefore doesn’t qualify for tax exemptions. The proposal is met with a "firestorm of protest."

gsx$mediacaption.$t: Senator Strom Thurmon was a vocal apponent of the IRS proposal to test if private schools met desegregation standards

content.$t:
headline: Congress nixes IRS testing, text: Days before congressional oversight hearings on the topic, the IRS replaces the test with a “milder version.” That still doesn’t fly with Congress, which bars the IRS from using money it receives to create or implement new regulations governing private or religious schools. , media: https://s3.amazonaws.com/iw-files/images/2014/IRS_timeline/MoynihanIRS.jpg, mediacredit: WikiCommons, mediacaption: Sen. Daniel Moynihan of New York criticized the Congressional ruling, stating "the administrative decision to 
reverse the established federal rule denying tax-exempt status to private schools and colleges that practice racial discrimination 
is . . . illegal."

gsx$text.$t: Days before congressional oversight hearings on the topic, the IRS replaces the test with a “milder version.” That still doesn’t fly with Congress, which bars the IRS from using money it receives to create or implement new regulations governing private or religious schools.

gsx$mediacaption.$t:
Sen. Daniel Moynihan of New York criticized the Congressional ruling, stating "the administrative decision to 
reverse the established federal rule denying tax-exempt status to private schools and colleges that practice racial discrimination 
is . . . illegal."

content.$t: headline: Uncomfortable indecision, text: General counsel memoranda — IRS parlance for legal analysis — become infrequent after federal court decisions require the agency to make them public. Debra Kawecki, a former senior IRS attorney, said those who wrote the memos, employees of a political appointee, grew more cautious over the years: “They were not comfortable coming out with opinions about anything.” , media: http://iw-files.s3.amazonaws.com/images/2014/IRS_timeline/IRSwall.jpg, mediacredit: Flickr

gsx$text.$t: General counsel memoranda — IRS parlance for legal analysis — become infrequent after federal court decisions require the agency to make them public. Debra Kawecki, a former senior IRS attorney, said those who wrote the memos, employees of a political appointee, grew more cautious over the years: “They were not comfortable coming out with opinions about anything.”

content.$t: headline: "Radioactive" tax exempts, text: President Ronald Reagan halts the IRS’s effort to crack down on private schools discriminating against black students by revoking their tax exemptions. The Justice and Treasury departments – both headed by political appointees – backed the administration’s position. The Supreme Court later ruled on a case that supported the IRS’s original position. Still, the episode showed “tax-exempt issues are radioactive. You will be burned,” said Marc Owens, a former exempt organizations director and employee., media: https://s3.amazonaws.com/iw-files/images/2014/IRS_timeline/bju.jpeg, mediacredit: WikiCommons, mediacaption: The IRS previously used tax exempt privilages as a way to enforce against racial discimination at private schools like Bob Jones University in South Carolina.

gsx$text.$t: President Ronald Reagan halts the IRS’s effort to crack down on private schools discriminating against black students by revoking their tax exemptions. The Justice and Treasury departments – both headed by political appointees – backed the administration’s position. The Supreme Court later ruled on a case that supported the IRS’s original position. Still, the episode showed “tax-exempt issues are radioactive. You will be burned,” said Marc Owens, a former exempt organizations director and employee.

gsx$mediacaption.$t: The IRS previously used tax exempt privilages as a way to enforce against racial discimination at private schools like Bob Jones University in South Carolina.

content.$t: headline: IRS rulings slow, text: The nonprofit regulation division’s “revenue rulings” — written IRS interpretations of contentious or unclear areas of tax law — plummet and never bounce back. Nearly nine in 10 of the rulings for the years 1977 through 2013 are issued during the eight years before 1982. Around then, the Treasury Department, which previously had “veto” power over the rulings, begin requiring active approval for them, according to former Treasury employees, media: http://iw-files.s3.amazonaws.com/images/2014/IRS_timeline/revenuerulingsIRS.png, mediacredit: Chris Zubak-Skees, Center for Public Integrity. Source: Internal Revenue Service documents and Center for Responsive Politics data.

gsx$text.$t: The nonprofit regulation division’s “revenue rulings” — written IRS interpretations of contentious or unclear areas of tax law — plummet and never bounce back. Nearly nine in 10 of the rulings for the years 1977 through 2013 are issued during the eight years before 1982. Around then, the Treasury Department, which previously had “veto” power over the rulings, begin requiring active approval for them, according to former Treasury employees

gsx$mediacredit.$t: Chris Zubak-Skees, Center for Public Integrity. Source: Internal Revenue Service documents and Center for Responsive Politics data.

content.$t: headline: Technology troubles, text: Technology-related problems at the IRS cause months-long delays in refunds for millions of taxpayers. The next year, the agency is subject to congressional hearings on the topic. The next few years, the agency shifts its focus to improving technology and implementing the Tax Reform Act of 1986. This period marks the first major drop in exempt organizations audits as a percentage of total nonprofits., media: https://s3.amazonaws.com/iw-files/images/2014/IRS_timeline/Reagan_Tax1986.jpg, mediacredit: National Archives, mediacaption: President Ronald Reagan's Remarks on Signing the Tax Reform Act into Law on the White House South Lawn, 10/22/1986

gsx$text.$t: Technology-related problems at the IRS cause months-long delays in refunds for millions of taxpayers. The next year, the agency is subject to congressional hearings on the topic. The next few years, the agency shifts its focus to improving technology and implementing the Tax Reform Act of 1986. This period marks the first major drop in exempt organizations audits as a percentage of total nonprofits.

gsx$mediacaption.$t: President Ronald Reagan's Remarks on Signing the Tax Reform Act into Law on the White House South Lawn, 10/22/1986

content.$t: headline: Tax returns for the church-affiliated, text: The IRS relaxes a proposed rule requiring colleges, hospitals, and other groups affiliated with churches to file informational tax returns. , media: https://s3.amazonaws.com/iw-files/images/2014/IRS_timeline/BYUbannerIRS.jpg, mediacredit: Ken Lund/Flickr , mediacaption: The revised IRS rules relaxed tax return requirements of institutions like Brigham Young University

gsx$text.$t: The IRS relaxes a proposed rule requiring colleges, hospitals, and other groups affiliated with churches to file informational tax returns.

gsx$mediacaption.$t: The revised IRS rules relaxed tax return requirements of institutions like Brigham Young University

content.$t: headline: Water-down lobbying rules draw fire, text: The IRS faces a “a big uproar” about proposed lobbying regulations for nonprofits in 1986 so it convenes an advisory panel to get feedback, said Ellen Aprill, a Loyola Law School-Los Angeles professor who then worked for the U.S. Treasury. “The regulations got redrafted and repurposed to be much more favorable to the charities,” she said.

gsx$text.$t: The IRS faces a “a big uproar” about proposed lobbying regulations for nonprofits in 1986 so it convenes an advisory panel to get feedback, said Ellen Aprill, a Loyola Law School-Los Angeles professor who then worked for the U.S. Treasury. “The regulations got redrafted and repurposed to be much more favorable to the charities,” she said.

content.$t: headline: A "Fourth-quarter choke", text: The IRS pulls what has been described as a “fourth-quarter choke:” It backs off its ruling that millions of dollars in payments to the nonprofit organizing the Cotton Bowl football game are a form of advertising — and subject to a 34 percent “unrelated business income tax.”, media: http://i245.photobucket.com/albums/gg73/JConly_2008/CottonBowl1993.jpg, mediacredit: Photobucket, mediacaption: Mobil paid about $1.6 million a year to the nonprofit Cotton Bowl organizers

gsx$text.$t: The IRS pulls what has been described as a “fourth-quarter choke:” It backs off its ruling that millions of dollars in payments to the nonprofit organizing the Cotton Bowl football game are a form of advertising — and subject to a 34 percent “unrelated business income tax.”

gsx$mediacaption.$t: Mobil paid about $1.6 million a year to the nonprofit Cotton Bowl organizers

content.$t: headline: New leadership, text: An eight-month Senate Finance Committee inquiry into IRS activities culminates in hearings grilling IRS officials about agency investigations they considered too aggressive. “That had a big impact on the IRS … the scare factor,” said Mark Scott, a former tax exempt bond division director. “You know how Congress is. They were having a show.” Charles Rossotti, the first IRS commissioner who isn’t a tax lawyer, oversees a cultural shift at the agency to improve “customer service.”

gsx$text.$t: An eight-month Senate Finance Committee inquiry into IRS activities culminates in hearings grilling IRS officials about agency investigations they considered too aggressive. “That had a big impact on the IRS … the scare factor,” said Mark Scott, a former tax exempt bond division director. “You know how Congress is. They were having a show.” Charles Rossotti, the first IRS commissioner who isn’t a tax lawyer, oversees a cultural shift at the agency to improve “customer service.”

content.$t: headline: Reorganization downsizes exempt organizations division, text: The exempt organizations division declares a key division goal is “enhancing the service provided to internal and external customers,” according to its internal planning guide. By that year, there are fewer than 13 full-time employee plan and exempt organizations regulators per 10,000 nonprofit organizations being regulated. This is down from about 23 per 10,000 in 1990., media: http://iw-files.s3.amazonaws.com/images/2014/IRS_timeline/jobschartIRS.png, mediacredit: Chris Zubak-Skees, Center for Public Integrity. Source: Internal Revenue Service documents and Center for Responsive Politics data.

gsx$text.$t: The exempt organizations division declares a key division goal is “enhancing the service provided to internal and external customers,” according to its internal planning guide. By that year, there are fewer than 13 full-time employee plan and exempt organizations regulators per 10,000 nonprofit organizations being regulated. This is down from about 23 per 10,000 in 1990.

gsx$mediacredit.$t: Chris Zubak-Skees, Center for Public Integrity. Source: Internal Revenue Service documents and Center for Responsive Politics data.

content.$t: headline: Another blow against consistancy , text: “Post-review” evaluations – requiring attorneys to review decisions on applications for exempt status – are no longer mandatory. Since post-reviews factored into field managers’ performance evaluations, employees would often ask attorneys for advice before deciding a complex case so as not to bungle it. Without the reviews, agents gained “more independence but there was less consistency and uniformity,” said Owens, the former exempt organizations director., media: https://iw-files.s3.amazonaws.com/images/2014/IRS_timeline/IMG_3844.jpg, mediacredit: Eleanor Bell/Center for Public Integrity, mediacaption: Marc Owens (left) meets with current and former IRS employees meet to improve the agency's efficiency

gsx$text.$t: “Post-review” evaluations – requiring attorneys to review decisions on applications for exempt status – are no longer mandatory. Since post-reviews factored into field managers’ performance evaluations, employees would often ask attorneys for advice before deciding a complex case so as not to bungle it. Without the reviews, agents gained “more independence but there was less consistency and uniformity,” said Owens, the former exempt organizations director.

gsx$mediacaption.$t: Marc Owens (left) meets with current and former IRS employees meet to improve the agency's efficiency

content.$t: headline: An end to continuing education books, text: The exempt organizations division kills its continuing professional education books — annual guides with hundreds of pages of information about key nonprofit issues — mainly because of the resources required to produce them. Employees are deeply disappointed because they say the guides allowed the authors to become experts in highly specialized subjects affecting nonprofit regulation and training sessions based on the books fostered teamwork and collaboration among different IRS offices., media: http://iw-files.s3.amazonaws.com/images/2014/IRS_timeline/Edited_IMG_5398.jpg, mediacredit: Eleanor Bell/Center for Public Integrity, mediacaption: Exempt organizations director John Koskinin

gsx$headline.$t: An end to continuing education books

gsx$text.$t: The exempt organizations division kills its continuing professional education books — annual guides with hundreds of pages of information about key nonprofit issues — mainly because of the resources required to produce them. Employees are deeply disappointed because they say the guides allowed the authors to become experts in highly specialized subjects affecting nonprofit regulation and training sessions based on the books fostered teamwork and collaboration among different IRS offices.

content.$t: headline: 29-year low for investigations, text: The number of IRS investigations for nonprofits — called examinations within the agency — hit a 29-year low. According to IRS data, 4,953 nonprofit tax returns are audited in fiscal year 2005, down from 23,807 in 1980. Regulators attempt to supplement full-blown examinations with more audits that are less intensive. Audits – counting “limited scope” reviews –  steadily increase the next six years., media: http://iw-files.s3.amazonaws.com/images/2014/IRS_timeline/percentauditedIRS.png, mediacredit: Chris Zubak-Skees, Center for Public Integrity. Source: Internal Revenue Service documents and Center for Responsive Politics data., mediacaption: IRS audits targeting nonprofits

gsx$text.$t: The number of IRS investigations for nonprofits — called examinations within the agency — hit a 29-year low. According to IRS data, 4,953 nonprofit tax returns are audited in fiscal year 2005, down from 23,807 in 1980. Regulators attempt to supplement full-blown examinations with more audits that are less intensive. Audits – counting “limited scope” reviews –  steadily increase the next six years.

gsx$mediacredit.$t: Chris Zubak-Skees, Center for Public Integrity. Source: Internal Revenue Service documents and Center for Responsive Politics data.

content.$t: headline: Citizens United, text: In Citizens United vs. Federal Election Commission, the Supreme Court allows corporations, unions and certain nonprofit groups to raise and spend unlimited amounts of money to advocate for or against politicians. About a month later, the IRS’s Cincinnati office flags a tea party group applying for tax-exempt status as a 501(c)(4) social welfare nonprofit, according to an exchange of emails among IRS employees., media: http://iw-files.s3.amazonaws.com/images/2014/IRS_timeline/Supremecourt2010IRS.jpg, mediacredit: Supreme Court, mediacaption: The Supreme Court in 2010

gsx$text.$t: In Citizens United vs. Federal Election Commission, the Supreme Court allows corporations, unions and certain nonprofit groups to raise and spend unlimited amounts of money to advocate for or against politicians. About a month later, the IRS’s Cincinnati office flags a tea party group applying for tax-exempt status as a 501(c)(4) social welfare nonprofit, according to an exchange of emails among IRS employees.

content.$t: headline: Senate Finance Committee criticizes IRS, text: The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee and six members of the Senate Finance Committee write letters criticizing the IRS’s investigations of whether a gift tax should apply to donations to social welfare organizations. Within two months, the IRS shuts down the investigations., media: https://iw-files.s3.amazonaws.com/images/2014/IRS_timeline/letterIRS.png, mediacaption: View document

gsx$text.$t: The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee and six members of the Senate Finance Committee write letters criticizing the IRS’s investigations of whether a gift tax should apply to donations to social welfare organizations. Within two months, the IRS shuts down the investigations.

content.$t: enddate: 6/2012, headline: Republicans alledge unfair targeting, text: From April to June, Congress questions the IRS about its review process for conservative organizations applying for status as 501(c)(4) “social welfare” nonprofits. A letter signed by 61 House Republicans says some applicants for social welfare status have “experienced extensive delays and received excessively burdensome information requests” from the agency. The Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration launches an investigation. , media: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Nf74vfbrB0o, mediacredit: House Ways and Means Youtube channel

gsx$text.$t: From April to June, Congress questions the IRS about its review process for conservative organizations applying for status as 501(c)(4) “social welfare” nonprofits. A letter signed by 61 House Republicans says some applicants for social welfare status have “experienced extensive delays and received excessively burdensome information requests” from the agency. The Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration launches an investigation.

gsx$mediacredit.$t: House Ways and Means Youtube channel

content.$t: headline: "Tea Party" a target, text: Lois Lerner, the IRS exempt organizations director, publicly acknowledges the IRS used search terms such as “tea party” to flag social welfare applicants for additional scrutiny — sparking a national scandal. Within days, the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration reports the IRS used improper criteria in determining groups’ nonprofit status. Politicians hold several hearings on the tea party matter and request the IRS produce various documents., media: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fOnmaVmaXGo, mediacredit: Richmond Tea Party Youtube, mediacaption: Richmond Tea Party call for an audit on the IRS

gsx$text.$t: Lois Lerner, the IRS exempt organizations director, publicly acknowledges the IRS used search terms such as “tea party” to flag social welfare applicants for additional scrutiny — sparking a national scandal. Within days, the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration reports the IRS used improper criteria in determining groups’ nonprofit status. Politicians hold several hearings on the tea party matter and request the IRS produce various documents.

gsx$mediacaption.$t: Richmond Tea Party call for an audit on the IRS

content.$t: headline: Continuing investigations cost $10 million, text: Politicians conduct additional IRS hearings and ask for more documents. As of March, the IRS reported providing 690,000 pages of documents to the Senate Finance Committee, including tens of thousands of IRS emails. As of June, the IRS reported spending about $10 million directly on the requests and an additional $6 million to $8 million on supporting costs., media: https://twitter.com/WaysandMeansGOP/status/469592559959179265, mediacredit: Twitter, mediacaption: The House Committee Ways and Means twitter account

gsx$text.$t: Politicians conduct additional IRS hearings and ask for more documents. As of March, the IRS reported providing 690,000 pages of documents to the Senate Finance Committee, including tens of thousands of IRS emails. As of June, the IRS reported spending about $10 million directly on the requests and an additional $6 million to $8 million on supporting costs.

gsx$mediacaption.$t: The House Committee Ways and Means twitter account
